page.title: 04HUNTROYDE PADIHAM
page.content: Huntroyde Desmesne was part of the{ {Honour of Clitheroe}granted to Roger of Poiton after the Norman Conquest. The land was used for hunting and in 1464 came into the possession of Edmund Starky, "in right of his wife, Elizabeth of Symondstone", and has belonged to the Starkie family ever since. During the civil war the family took the Parliamentarian side and were responsible for raising the local militia. They have provided five{Sheriffs of Lancashire}and been benefactors to the town of Padiham. Over the centuries the use of the land has changed and now 85% is used for dairy farming and the rest for sheep. There is a Home Farm and several cottages and houses. In 1983 the Starkies left{Huntroyde Hall,}which is now divided into two residences, and the land is managed by an agent.
